FacilityName: Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill shut-off device at 85% vessel fill, Class 1, Div.1 electrical from transfer point to 5ft.  Class I, Div.2 from 5-15ft., Labels on cylinders (NFPA 704, Not Odorized, No Smoking, etc.)
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Portable 20 lb. fire extinguishers and hydrants.  Excess flow valves, pressure relief valves.  Thermal actuated valves.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Temperature, Pressure, and Level Indicators w/alarms/shut-offs.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Level III:  Butane (liquified butane under pressure) blending system involving direct injection into refined product (gasoline) pipelines with dual bulk truck off-loading.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association Code #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the Facility's policy to follow the most current edition to the extent feasible and adhere to all Federal, State, and Local codes/laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is the Facility's policy to contact the Bethel Township Hose Company and the Delaware County LEPC, as appropriate through the 911 Service.  Medical emergencies will require notification of Concord 59 and Talleyville 25 (both Basic Life Support Units) or Medic 104 (Advanced Life Support unit) via 911 for ambulance service.  The primary hospital response is provided through Crozier Chester Medical Center with support through Riddle Hospital.  The Facility is not currently designated a "responding" facility, however, the Facility maintains a trained incipient stage fire response and first responder-operations level hazardous materials response teams to respond to the initial stages of an emergency.



Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station is a refined product pipeline breakout station, including the butane blending system (direct injection into the pipelines).  The Risk Management Plan covers the butane blending system including three 60,000 gallon vessels, truck offloading stations, and associated sampling and transfer equipment.



Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D - Program Level 3).  Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor - Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management regulations (inclusive of all 14 elements) for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR Part 1910.119).



To date, this Facility has never had an accident or incident involving the butane blending system resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmenta

l damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Booth Station butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Bethel Township Hose Company and request their assistance. The Facility's Emergency Response Plans are coordinated with the Bethel Township Hose Company and the Delaware County LEPC.  The Bethel Township Hose Company is aware of the Facility's butane blending system.  Fire Department access is via Garnet Mine Road.  Available fire protection includes onsite fire hydrants and portable (20 lb.) dry chemical fire extinguishers.  The Booth Station maintains a vegetation control plan to minimize plant growth within 10 feet of the butane vessels.



Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P. continually evaluates the process for opportunities to improve safety.  Also, Laurel Pipe Line Company L.P. makes every effort to coordinate annually at minimum with local responders.
